data.title: [Linux] Keyboard hotkeys not working
data.body: Hotkeys for things like Undo, Redo, Save, Close file, Copy, Paste, Play, Build etc are not working in Linux (or at least Arch Linux). Nothing happens when trying to use hotkeys, however clicking the menu options works.

data.title: remove unused dependency on ATL
data.body: This should make building with VC++ Build Tools and mingw easier.

data.title: Component Inspector: Provide custom inspector widgets for complex data
data.body:
For JS Components, it would be useful to be able to define custom inspector widgets.  This could be accomplished by having a new var type called: `Atomic.VAR_CUSTOM` or `Atomic.VAR_JSON` that could be defined with a key that indicates which custom editor to use.

An example might be something like

```
inspectorFields = {
  jsonField: [Atomic.VAR_JSON, "{}"],
  customField: [Atomic.VAR_CUSTOM, ["MyEditorName", "{}"]]
}
```

For a `VAR_JSON` a free-form text entry field could pop up to be edited and then saved back into the object.  For a `VAR_CUSTOM`, an inspector registered with the provided editor name could pop up.  If that editor doesn't exist, then maybe the JSON editor could pop up.  Both of these editors would read and write JSON data to/from the field.

In order to provide custom inspectors, the logic that determines which inspector widget to use for each field would need to be tweaked to use some kind of registry or locator and then this could be exposed to editor extensions that could add additional widgets to this registry.

When instantiating these fields on a custom JSComponent, the stored JSON would need to be parsed back into object form and attached to the field on the JSComponent.  This would allow the component at run-time to be able to interact with a fleshed out object and not need to parse the values beforehand.

data.title: Basic editing key bindings for Linux
data.body:
Add the arrow, backspace, delete to the Linux Ace editor, making for an enjoyable editing experience.
To say CEF support for linux is a little weak would not be an understatement. After trying to find the right combinations of key events, states, values, I found, by looking at the CEF browser unit tests for GTK, that they were translating GTK key scancodes to Windows scancodes, then using the methodology that windows uses to talk to the embedded browser. Now if that had been documented, it would have been done faster.
There will need to be still more follow on work to handle translation for the function and keypad keys, and making sure the full set of ace key bindings work.

data.title: Remove dependency on ATL
data.body:
I've been working on getting a headless build working on Windows using a clean Windows10 VM and then installing git, cmake, and vcbuildtools with Chocolatey as a way of having a relatively lightweight way to build in Windows.

The build fails because atlbase.h is included in AtomicGameEngine/Source/ThirdParty/nativefiledialog/nfd_win.cpp. Which use to be in the PSDK then removed, and then use to be in the DDK then removed and now it isn't in the vcbuildtools or VS Express either.

So after spending way more time than I would like to admit trying to find a clean way to pull the 1mb of files out of a 650mb iso of the old DDK from microsoft downloads I got frustrated and commented it out to see what the 'actual' dependencies were... and there aren't any, the file is just dependency rot.

I can either submit a PR back to the original project, which already has a healthy list of forgotten PRs or submit a PR to the ThirdParty sources here.

I think removing it is worth doing so there can be a lightweight build alternative for folks who don't need the full visual studio space hog install, and also makes it easy to automate the creation of a build environment which might help on-boarding with people new to building.

Thoughts..?

data.title: [NEW FEATURE] SWIG for interop?
data.body:
Just putting this here for visibility.

Came across SWIG which seems to promise autogeneration of headers, etc and binding for potential for C# _and_ Java?

Would be cool to be able to use groovy on JVM or C#.

I tried to dive into it but without more direction I dont quite have the skillset.

data.title: fix for compiling with gcc 6.1.1 on Arch Linux
data.body: Tested with Ubuntu  GCC 5.3 and has no effect in older compilers

data.title: [NEW FEATURE] Key / mouse / gesture combo
data.body:
Would be nice to be able to use cmd + 3-finger-drag to rotate camera in SceneView3D.

There is already an issue logged to add editor settings, exposing things like this to be configurable. right now working in the scene editor on macbook with trackpad only is a bit painful

data.title: Linux display issues with complex 3d models, Shadows
data.body: The linux Mesa display drivers has problems with complex 3d models and shadows. The toontown is really bad with the procsky, it'll be fine, then a visual mess, the model vertexes go bonkers, then it's fine again depending on the position of the sun. Urho3d has the same problem. When I run a Urho3D program on linux I have to add "-gl2 -noshadows" to the command line to make the display behave.

data.title: Support both tabbed and space indents for TB ui files
data.body:
(Though not mixed in same file)

Closes #67

data.title: UI Skin preference
data.body:
This PR will allow the user to change the editor's skin and default font. The process is done by editing the prefs.json file.  Editable fields and default values are :
    "skinPath": "AtomicEditor/editor/skin/"
    "defaultSkinPath": "AtomicEditor/resources/default_skin/"
    "fontFile": "AtomicEditor/resources/vera.ttf"
    "fontName": "Vera"
    "fontSize": 12

To change to the editor's look to the light skin, modify these values in the prefs.json file.
    "skinPath": "AtomicEditor/editor/skin_light/"
    "defaultSkinPath": "AtomicEditor/resources/default_skin_light/"

data.title: Add common user settings dialog
data.body:
There needs to be a common user settings dialog that will house all of the application settings as well as any extension provided settings.  My thought would be to have a list along the left side with each setting category and then a panel in the center.  

When the dialog initializes, it could iterate over a list of registered user preference providers to populate the list on the side and then when one is selected, request the panel that should be loaded in.

data.title: Expose ACE options in the userprefs.json file
data.body:
This PR addresses the ability to configure the Ace editor from the application settings file.  Until there is a dedicated extensible user settings dialog, this is going to need to be hand-edited for now (I'll add an issue for creating a settings dialog)

Currently the following settings are exposed in `userprefs.json`

``` json
  "codeEditorSettings": {
    "theme": "ace/theme/monokai",
    "keyboardHandler": "ace/keyboard/textinput",
    "fontSize": 12,
    "showInvisibles": false,
    "useSoftTabs": true,
    "tabSize": 2
  }
```

I reworked the way settings are exposed to the web view and instead of having the web view request the settings through an AJAX call, the settings are placed onto the WebHost global properties.  This allows them to be available as soon as possible so that when the editor configures itself, it can get the settings.  I also modified the notification for preferences changes and just send a simple notification message that the values in the WebHost global have been updated.  This is a lot less chatty and actually feels like a cleaner implementation.

@JimMarlowe - this should give you the ACE configuration part of the skin updates you are looking at.

I contemplated having editor settings for each file type, but I think until there is dedicated UI for it, it could get too complex.

data.title: Component Copy Paste (with POD string format fix)
Grid functionality rebased onto mouse speed change branch
Mouse wheel adjustment for Scene editor camera speed
data.body: Fixes OSX mouse wheel from https://github.com/AtomicGameEngine/AtomicGameEngine/pull/850

data.title: New navigation
data.body:
Hi @JoshEngebretson 

Changed how to increase and decrease camera speeds. You no longer use shift key. You can simply hold down the right mouse button and adjust the speed using the mouse wheel.

No longer have to use alt to zoom in and out. Adjust the zoom using only the mouse wheel. It will zoom in on where the mouse pointer is or the object selected.

data.title: Grid implementation
data.body:
Hi @JoshEngebretson 

Added a grid to the sceneview.
Can be toggled using the letter "G" key.
Currently only have a set number of grid lines.

data.title: Orthographic views
data.body:
Hi @JoshEngebretson 

Added switching from perspective- to orthographic views. 
Added snapping to a specific view if an object is selected. If no object is selected the camera wil snap to the view relative to its position.

Things you are able to do:
1. Switch between perspective and orthographic using "O" key.
2. Snap to an orthographic view using keys 1-6.
   (I was very unsure as to which keys I should assign this to)
   1-Top
   2-Bottom
   3-Left
   4-Right
   5-Front
   6-Back
3. You can switch back to perspective by pressing the letter "O" key even after pressing keys 1-6.
4. It will remember the perspective position you were in before switching to orthographic. You can revert to that position by pressing the letter "P" key.
5. Can zoom while in orthographic using the mouse wheel

data.title: Copy paste tool for components
data.body:
Hi @JoshEngebretson 

Made it possible to let you copy and paste the settings of one component on a node to a similar component on a different node.

Can not copy and paste to different components as expected.

If nothing is copied nothing will paste as also expected

data.title: Automated unit testing of Editor code
data.body:
Need a way to generate automated tests for the editor code and the web view editor code.  

For the web view editor code, it should be possible to mock the interface to the host and do some automated testing there with some standard JS unit testing tools such as Mocha or Jasmine.

For the editor code, however, there probably needs to be some brainstorming.  It can either be done by mocking all of the Atomic interfaces.  Or, if there is a way to either run a headless Atomic instance or kick off the editor with some special command line switches that has it run some automated tests and then return the results to the shell would be ideal.

I'm putting this here so it's at least registered as an issue, but needs some thought.

data.title: Support TS and ES6 style 'export default' for components
data.body:
To make components cleaner, an enhancement would be to support `export default` for components.  This would change components from being defined as:

``` typescript
class MyComponent extends Atomic.JSComponent {
...
}
export = MyComponent;
```

to simply

``` typescript
export default class MyComponent extends Atomic.JSComponent {
...
}
```

The logic would need to look for a property called `default` on the module because the transpiled JS looks like

``` javascript
exports.default = MyComponent
```
